This is to compensate for the difference between the actual location, as measured by GPS, and the location displayed on Google Maps. --> | broke_ground = 1991 | built = | opened = June 1992 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = Newcastle Showground & Exhibition Centre Trust | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = [[Australian dollar|A$]]12m | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Newcastle Falcons (Australia)|Newcastle Falcons]] ([[National Basketball League (Australia)|NBL]]) (1992-1999)<br />[[Hunter Jaegers]] ([[Commonwealth Bank Trophy|CBT]]) (1997-2008)<br />[[Hunter Pirates]] (NBL) (2003-2006) | seating_capacity = 6,500<br />[[Basketball]] / [[Netball]]: 4,658 | dimensions = {{Convert|54.4|x|79.3|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} | scoreboard = }} '''Newcastle Entertainment Centre''' is a multi-purpose Australian [[arena]] located within the Newcastle Showgrounds and was opened in 1992 at a cost of [[Australian dollar|A$]]12m. The centre's original tenant was the [[Newcastle Falcons (Australia)|Newcastle Falcons]] [[National Basketball League Australia|NBL]] team who moved to the new venue in 1992 from their previous home at the [[Broadmeadow Basketball Stadium]]. After the Falcons folded at the end of the 1999 season its only tenant was the [[Hunter Jaegers]] [[netball]] team who played in the [[Commonwealth Bank Trophy]]. The Jaegers played in the centre from 1997 until 2008. From 2003 the NEC served as the home court for another NBL team, the [[Hunter Pirates]] (formerly the [[Canberra Cannons]] before the team was moved to [[Singapore]] to become the [[Singapore Slingers]] after the [[2005-06 NBL season]]). The Newcastle Showgrounds themselves also housed the early [[Newcastle Rebels]] back in 1908-1909. This [[rugby league]] franchise played two seasons in the [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership]]. The Entertainment Centre is renowned for being one of Australia's most flexible [[multi-purpose stadium]]s, able to accommodate sports events, various performances and expos. The [[Newcastle Show]] uses the Centre for various displays and the showbag area. The stadium has also played host to some of [[Kostya Tszyu]]'s early fights as an Australian-based fighter. The venue has a listed seating capacity of 4,658, but it can host anywhere between 2,000 to 6,500 for various events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=76|title=Australian Stadiums :: Newcastle Entertainment Centre|publisher=austadiums.com|accessdate=2008-04-07}}</ref> The stadium is air-conditioned (installed as a requirement of the NBL when it moved to playing in the summer), equipped with top-grade lights, and also has scoreboards used for basketball and netball games. The stadium is controlled by the [[Newcastle Showground and Exhibition Centre Trust]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.nec.net.au/ Newcastle Entertainment Centre website] {{City of Newcastle suburbs}} {{Hunter Region places and items of interest}} {{NBL Arenas}} {{ANZ Championship Arenas}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Australia]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Australia]] [[Category:Netball venues in Australia]] [[Category:Newcastle, New South Wales]] [[Category:Music venues in Australia]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in Australia]] [[Category:Boxing venues]] [[Category:Mixed martial arts venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in New South Wales]] {{Australia-sports-venue-stub}}
